headline: CNN Live Event/Special
subHeadline: CNN Presents "Juneteenth: A Global Celebration Of Freedom." Aired 11p-12a ET

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: What a show. You can hear everyone screaming, Charlie! Charlie! You just heard Charlie Wilson from the "The Gap Band." And as a solo artist, he still got it. We heard Nelly, we heard Chloe bringing the house down. This has been an incredible show of talent. And so many inspirational remarks honoring this federal holiday. It is now a federal holiday, Juneteenth. And it's all about freedom.We are back with "Juneteenth on CNN." I'm Sara Sidner along with Van Jones. It just keeps getting better and better. There are moments from now, we are going to be talking to some of the folks that you saw on the stage, some of the headliners, Kirk Franklin, Big Freedia, the members of SWV. (LAUGHTER) They are all going to show up. We are going to get to -- to ham it up with them a little bit. It was amazing.

utterances.speaker: VAN JONES, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: Look, I just -- I'm so -- I'm proud to be an American, I'm proud to be Black, I'm proud to CNN, I'm proud of -- I'm proud of Kirk Franklin be van. It's like -- it's an unbelievable show. And you had the young folks.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: This is -- I guarantee you, there are some people who never heard of Chloe --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: -- who now knows who she is. But I tell you what, Charlie, he still got.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Charlie brought the house down. I mean --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: He still got it.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- I love seeing people who love their craft and can do it -- JONES

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- for their entire lives.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Entire lives.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It is beautiful. Now, speaking of a little surprise, a little coolness, a little duet --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- we saw someone we were not expecting to see. Nelly and Chloe.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Nelly and Cloe.

utterances.speaker: SIDNEY
utterances.sentences: They came together. We didn't know this was going to happen. Let's let you see what happened.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: If you missed it.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) (NELLY AND CHLOE PERFORMING) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Come on, Chloe and Nelly.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: That works. That works.(LAUGHTER) The two generations coming together.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It's just like, look, I mean, for me -- first of all, she was injured. She was out there. She had a boot on.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: She had a boot on.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: She was injured. Made it better out there. They made it work.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: They made it. They sauce it up.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: They made it work.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: They did. It was nice to see. There is a generational --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- coming together, as you mentioned.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: That's what Juneteenth does. It brings together --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: -- the old and the young, and we showed it on the stage tonight. You know, the thing that I was shocked by was Mike Phillips. When he came out -- look, when you think about instrumentalist, you think about a jazz person. Okay, that's great. All of a sudden, wait, this guy has Michael Jordan backing him and giving him a shoe. What kind of instrumentalist is going to get a shoe?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Same kind of instrumentalist that showed up. And the crowd went nuts.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Went nuts.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Like literally --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- all of a sudden, they blew up. They were kind of chilling.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Big star. He was a big star of the night. Can we show some of that? In case you missed it.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Do we -- okay, let's go ahead and listen to some of that.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) (MIKE PHILLIPS PERFORMING)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: He is playing with the crowd. Look!

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Look at the crowd. That is the reaction. That is unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Come on.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: One man, one horn, and just tore it up.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: That takes so much strength. Look -- look at the crowd.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Look at that.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Sometimes, you talk to your neighbor, not like that.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Not today, folks. Speaking of someone we really want to talk to, let's bring in Stephanie Elam. You were there at the concert, at The Greek Theatre. Stephanie, what did you see in the crowd? I mean, you are just beaming as usual.(LAUGHTER) What did you see? (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: STEPHANIE ELAM, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Wait, you guys are talking about Mike Phillips. Let me tell you --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: -- when he came on the stage, we were like, okay, we like some saxophone, we want a group with some saxophone, and then he went off, and the crowd was on its feet! Mike Phillips tore the house down! He got everybody up.And I don't even understand how he was breathing and dancing. And those notes were so dank on long (ph). It was exciting. It was an amazing performance to see. And I know you guys are going to get to talk to him. I got to talk to him already. He is fantastic. I want you to meet a couple of people who have been enjoying the show, have been having the time of the night. Come on. This is Joanne and Lashawn (ph). Tell me, what was your favorite performance? I know it's hard.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: SWV.(SINGING)

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: You have the words. But I don't think you were alone. Did you hear everybody else singing along with you?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yes, everybody.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: All the words or did you forget any?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: No.(SINGING) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: So, was that what you guys were here, because you want to see SWV?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: No. I want to see Kirk Franklin.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Charlie Wilson and Nelly. I wanted to see them all. It was a great hit. I would not miss it for the world.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: So, tell me, tell me, though, Juneteenth, celebrating Juneteenth, was this something that was new to your -- part of your celebrations of the year or have you been doing this?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I have been doing this for the last three years.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: The last three years.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: This is my first year doing Juneteenth.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: What does it mean to have this holiday?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: We finally have this day. Everybody else has their day. We have our day. Today.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: And it's a paid (ph) holiday.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: For everybody. Right? For everybody. Right. So, well, I'm so glad that you, guys, had an enjoyable time. Thanks for talking to me. Thanks for grooving with me because we heard the end of Uncle Charlie here. Charlie Wilson was still singing. So, we were grooving a little bit over here. But a good time, Sara.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I mean, can we have -- can they sing us out?(SINGING)

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: Okay.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: They want you to sing us out.(SINGING)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You are hired. Keep jamming.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: You asked. You asked.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I did ask. And I appreciate it. Let us also go ahead -- they talked about Kirk Franklin, wanting to see him.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I certainly love to see him. He's my personal hype man in my head in the mornings.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: On the playlist every morning.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Let's listen to -- he sat down with us. He was so cool. Let's listen to what he had to say.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) (KIRK FRANKLIN PERFORMING) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Gospel great (ph) Kirk Franklin kicking off the Juneteenth concert with "Lift Every Voice and Sing," widely considered to be the Black national anthem. It is the Black national anthem.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It's not considered.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's not considered. It is the Black national anthem.

utterances.speaker: KIRK FRANKLIN, SINGER
utterances.sentences: There's no cap in it.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: There's no cap. Oh, look at you. Look at you, hanging with the people. I love it. You are my personal height man (ph) in the morning. I just want to let you know.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I'm always saying that you have a song.(SINGING)

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And I play it to get my mood up.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: First of all, did you hear the little note she is singing?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: It was really about (INAUDIBLE).(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Ladies and gentlemen, I want you to know this was not about me. This is the opportunity (INAUDIBLE). That was a major (INAUDIBLE) on CNN.(LAUGHTER) Because you didn't know what it was. (SINGING) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You have no idea. I had laryngitis before.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I haven't spoken for four days. I finally got rid of that. And now, I am sitting next to you. It is tripping me out right now.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: I am sitting with you and --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And Van. He is a legend.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: So great. He just asked for my number, ladies and gentlemen. I put my number in, and my name pops up. He already got my number. They act like they don't like to call you.(LAUGHTER) SIDNER:  It did say superstar under there, so -- I mean --

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: You know, Monday through Friday was terrible. Saturday, we try to get relief, but Sunday morning, Sunday morning. And now, you have brought that to a global audience. The old folks love you. You are working with Maverick City. The young folks love you. You are now -- you are now the central bridge builder within gospel.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) How does it feel? And there you are, doing your thing tonight.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: On Juneteenth. I mean, they love you.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Look at you.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: What is it like being out there, on this day, to see that reaction? And you are from Texas, right? Fort Worth.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: I'm a Texan boy.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: A Texan boy.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: So, this all went down in Texas in 1865.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And here you are in 2023. And look at you.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: I'm just very graceful, romantic. I feel the Lord. And it's just very interesting, being in Texas. We were always within the context of Juneteenth. And I would have friends that live in other parts of the country.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: And they did not really know what it was. But because in the south, it was so much a part of the esthetic of who we were as people, it is just a beautiful thing now to see that as a country --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: -- we are acknowledging that there are some pieces of history that need to be magnified so we can understand the gravity --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: -- of where we have been and where we are still trying to go.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Well, listen, it's a federal holiday. It's gone from being something that Black folks in Texas kept alive, barbecues --

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: -- and just spoken word. And now, it is a federal holiday signed into law by Biden, who was a part of this thing.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: And it would not have happened if Black folks in Texas had not fought for it. So how does that feel knowing that you took it from Texas?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Particularly Opal Lee.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Opal Lee herself.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: I know, crazy. It's very humbling. But once again, I think that it is still a very interesting dichotomy of this -- the space that we live within, you know, this western culture of always having to argue for points that should be self-explanatory.And I just think -- but at the same time, I celebrate the allies. You know? I celebrate my brothers and sisters that are not part of our experience, but they understand how important it is to the tapestry of American history that we get it right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Get it right.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You talk a lot in your music. You share a lot about struggles. Struggles that we all have, human beings in general.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And you have struggled. You have struggled with the concept of organized religion.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Still do.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And here you are like --

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Still do.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- the most popular contemporary gospel singer. How did that happen? How do you get through that struggle? And you said you are still going through?

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: I'm still going through it. I'm not the -- I'm just the one of the great communities of gospel artists. There are several. (INAUDIBLE), Yolanda Adams, Fred Hammond. I mean, you can just keep going on and on. I am just one of the links in the great chain. So, you know --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Humbly said.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, it's true. I think that I struggle through it by being very vocal. And I think that is something very healing because there has been such weaponization within the framework of western Christianity that has been -- not been official to the ongoing narrative of what faith is. I think it is duplicitous to not acknowledge the mistakes that have been made so that people can feel that there can be some honesty and transparency in the church.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: The church is a human institution, those kind of human thoughts and flaws. But is divinely inspired. And music, you have been a part of that. Listen, I think all of black theology can be summed up in two words, whether you're talking about Dr. King, whether you're talking about (INAUDIBLE). Hallelujah, anyhow. Hallelujah, anyhow. No matter what you do to us, you are not going to take away our joy. You are not going to tell us that we're not children of God. That is your message.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: He is like the preacher in you.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) right now.(LAUGHTER) We would let some Baptist church up on the roof. (LAUGHTER) You know, that's beautifully said. I think that that can be everyone's statement. That you just do not have the -- you don't have to have the same hubris (ph) as I do --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: -- to be able to understand that no matter what we face, collectively, at the end of it, it is a hallelujah anyhow. And so, you know, me being from the south, being adopted, going through abandonment, not having a mother and father, and I'm sitting up here with you, legends, you know, in journalism, for mem, that's the hallelujah, anyhow.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Look, we feel the same way because you have uplifted us.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: We hear your voice every day.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Truly.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Sorry about that.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It's my playlist, it's on my playlist.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And you help us transcend. And that is a blessing to all of us.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Thank you. And I think that the message there is, you know, if all -- if what you see is all you see, then you do not see all there is to be seen. You know?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Dang.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: That's not mine. That's Dr. Tony Evers.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I know but dang. You got it memorized.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Because I'm a student of just truth and I am always trying to tap into things that make us better. It's because the journey is difficult. You know? And there are so many whys. You know, why would a loving God allow so much trauma in the world? Sometimes, I don't know. But what I don't know does not cancel out what I do know.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Love it, love it.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Now, that is mine.(LAUGHTER) (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Come on.(LAUGHTER) Kirk Franklin, you are the best.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: That's good.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much for taking part in all this.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Look at this.

utterances.speaker: FRANKLIN
utterances.sentences: And a solo album is coming out. Solo album coming out next week. It drops. It's an album called "Lady in Pink."(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Heard it right here. Kirk Franklin just said it. Let's get that signed. All right.(LAUGHTER) Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It feels so good.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: There they go. There they go. There they go.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Come on. That was the legendary R&B trio SWV --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- getting the Juneteenth crowd. And us. We are part of it, going. So, I am just letting you all know, I am so in to you. Like --(LAUGHTER) I am. I was so excited when I saw your name. Hold on, I've got a little girl like freak out for a second there. I am so happy to see you. I am so happy to see you performing. Can you tell me what it is like to be out there? You guys have been around for a minute. I mean, we are young. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: We are all very young.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: We are all very young. But you've been doing this for a minute. And you come out to this crowd, and they lose their ever- messing minds. JONES

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's the music.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: It's the music.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's all about the music.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Exciting. We walked out there. We didn't really know what to expect. And they were loving us, and it was like, okay, let's get it.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: We wish everyone can feel how we feel. But you can't duplicate that feeling when you hear hundreds and thousands of people screaming your lyrics back to you.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's crazy.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It transcended the screen, too, because we were, like, okay, they know what we know.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Exactly. And part of the thing, too, is freedom can be fun. Freedom can be celebratory. Every time we get together and talk about black stuff, we shouldn't be crying and --

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Let's have fun.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: They did have a good time. Isn't that a part of freedom?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's a celebration.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Exactly, it's a celebration.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: A celebration.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: When you guys came out, the crowd went nuts. Every line, every lyric. You know how that feel, to know that all this time, everybody knows every word. Not just a couple words.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's so funny because they know the words and we forget them.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You all three are from New York, right?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Okay. And SWV, I looked this up when I was younger. Sisters with voices. We thought it was so incredibly cool. Does that mean something more to you? Because right now, sisters are having a lot of impact on a lot of things, whether it be politics.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Politics, culture --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Everything, from politics to culture, food, you name it.

utterances.speaker: TAMARA JOHNSON, MEMBER OF SWV
utterances.sentences: It is a sign of the times and progression. There was a time when we couldn't even come outside without permission. But now, we are laying down laws and putting foot down on folks. That is what we are talking about.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Kamala Harris was here. The first Black female vice president was here talking about sisters with voices. But you guys for a while, you weren't sisters with voices. You guys went separate ways. What made you come back together to become sisters with voices?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Stronger together than we are apart.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: That's who we all, everyone, as a nation, needs to understand, we are stronger together than apart.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: We knew that no matter how great we did without each other, it was not compared to what we can do together.

utterances.speaker: LEANNE LYONS, MEMBER OF SWV
utterances.sentences: Sisters with voices is not just our name. It is actually a movement.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LYONS
utterances.sentences: It really is.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: That is beautiful.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: That was obvious last night.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: That is beautiful. Speaking of sisters with voices, Stephanie Elam is down there. She is my sister from another Mr. I love this woman. She has been listening. She was there watching it in person.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Hey, girl.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Hey, girl.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: I hear them, I hear them. Listen, I have to tell you, I have to tell you, being in the audience and seeing everyone jump up, and I'm going to be honest, I was singing along to every word because you guys are kind of the soundtrack to some like important years in life. When I got to Howard University, everyone was singing SWV.I had to stop singing, though, because I listened, the entire audience was singing every single word. People were there for you. People were like, look at their shoes, look at the smooth moves. Everything. Taking in the entire vibe. I mean, I just had to stop and soak it up for you on your behalf. Like this is fantastic. But I was thinking about that for you. When people hear you singing and they're like this is like the soundtrack of like my youth, how does that feel for you, guys, to know that people feel that tie to your music?

utterances.speaker: CHERYL GAMBLE, MEMBER OF SWV
utterances.sentences: It feels great. You know, we have to focus because I will bust out crying any minute.(LAUGHTER) So, that is okay.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: There are groups that were around in your day would have that same reaction.

utterances.speaker: LYONS
utterances.sentences: That's what music does. Music is universal for everybody to enjoy.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: Wait, can I ask one more follow-up on that? Can I ask one more follow-up?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. Also, before you ask the follow-up, I'm trying to prove a point here. It is possible? Can we show the shoes? Lift those shoes up, ladies, if you can. There they are. Look at that. Come on. We get teased for wearing flats. I think they are fantastic and marvelous. It's what everybody is doing now.

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: It's comfortable, it's cute, it's chic, it's all how you wear it. It's not just a sneaker.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Shout out to our stylist, J. Bolin.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Oh, I see him over there. Well, you know what? He knows his thing because I see him over there. Stephanie, what's your question, girl?

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: Okay, I want to ask SWV, if you can confirm for me, who is the man singing S, W to the V, V? Who is that singing?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Pharrell Williams (ph).

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Nobody knew that.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: I heard it was Pharrell (ph).

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Let me tell you who knew that. Stephanie knew that. That was a trick question. ELAM

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It was him.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: That's amazing little trivia that people do not know.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: That is the news tonight.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: We had Pharrell (ph) before you guys do.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: You sure did.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: He was a baby in the studio.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: What was it like working with him? You did it because he was in the studio, did his little (INAUDIBLE) and then --

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: You should ask him how it was working with us.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Oh, they're right.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Come on. Okay, okay. Last question to you. What makes you feel free? I'm going to start with you.

utterances.speaker: GAMBLE
utterances.sentences: Honestly, I just recently cut my hair and I feel so free. It's been a few months. And I just feel free. Release the stress. I'm feeling good about myself.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Black woman and our hair, there's a lot going on there. There is a lot of emotion that goes on in there. There's a lot of judgment that comes our way. So, that is beautiful. What for you?

utterances.speaker: JOHNSON
utterances.sentences: I think, for me, just being able to love my family the way I want to, when I want to, how I want to. I just really find liberation in that because I know that my son is in a better place because I was able to do for him what I could not have when I was younger. So that freedom, I love that.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Beautiful.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Beautiful.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Generational.

utterances.speaker: LYONS
utterances.sentences: And what makes me feel free is just enjoying my body like getting older, it's like a thing and you always want to be like, you go through these changes like the midlife crisis thing, but I can actually be naked and be like, I look good for my age.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Tell the truth.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: LYONS
utterances.sentences: Those curves, that little love handles, take it or leave it.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's the confidence which you all have. And you get that as you get older. You start saying, like, I don't have to listen to what people are saying about me, I know me, I'm good. I'm good, thank you.I'm so happy to see you all. Thank you, thank you, thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Thank you for having us.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: That is hip-hop artist Big Freedia working the stage at The Greek Theatre tonight, performing "Motivate You." Now, guess what? We got Big Freedia right here with us. It is going to be more exciting. Thank you so much for being here.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA, SINGER
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: When you're doing a performance like that --

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- and your energy is -- is that music? They bounce.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: They give energy.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: They give energy. But does it take a lot out of you when you're up there and you just have to go through it and be at the highest energy? Everyone is expecting that from you.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Most definitely. Well, you know, I feed off the audience. So, the energy that they give me, I give it back.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: So, it's an even exchange.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: What was it like tonight?

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: It was awesome. It was Juneteenth. We were celebrating.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Freedom.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Yes, freedom for sure.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And you had a different kind of freedom. A new pace of freedom. How does that feel?

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: It feels really great. It felt like our Independence Day. And we really celebrate it for our people, and for them making it a national holiday as well is amazing.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: This is a time when a lot of people have a lot of fear. There's a lot of fear that is going around --

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: -- from some of the political divides and just the way that we are with one another. We've got a little bit mean with each other.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: We need more love.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I was going to ask, what is your message?

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: We need more love out here in this world.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: More love.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Stephanie Elam was watching you in person. She is down there at The Greek. We are way up here on a top of the building. She was down in The Greek enjoying her life. Big Freedia is with us. Is there anything you want to say to her? Listen, listen, you need to see all of this bling over here.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: Oh, Big Freeida, I could see -- I could see all of the bling from my seat. I noticed, too. It's like all the bling, I was like, oh, that goes up. But no, it's just so much. And I was noticing how people were just learning about your music and feeling the vibe. I saw people jumping up the more you were performing.And I was just wondering, as you are performing and you see people reacting like that, starting to get into the groove, what does it do for you while you are on stage?

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Just gives me a better feeling to go even harder. You know, I want to get more people out of their seats.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You won a Grammy.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Yes, I did.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Tell me about that moment.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Big Freedia just dropped Beyonce. I'll be thinking about Beyonce.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Most definitely.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Bounce movement is a positive movement, kind of EDM and kind of hip-hop. Talk about (INAUDIBLE) for people who don't know what that is yet.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: You know, it's New Orleans-based music. It got a lot to do with hurricane (ph) and shaking and all of that, but we also express freedom through dance. We have the girls' power and the boys' power. I just recently did a song with "Gracie's Corner." So, it bounces (ph) for everybody.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's incredible to see you perform and do it so freely.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Yeah, most definitely.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: What makes you feel the most free?

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: you know, my mom gave me confidence to be who I am. And, you know, and my church. My church home accepted me for who I was, allowed me to be free, allowed me to be musically-inclined. So, they gave me the motivation that I need to go out there and show them who I am.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: You did it, and you do it. We love it.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And so do the Grammys.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's yours.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) Beyonce.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Big Freedia, thank you so much. Appreciate you being on.

utterances.speaker: BIG FREEDIA
utterances.sentences: You already know.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Davido singing his new hit single "Unavailable," another stand-up performance at the Juneteenth concert tonight. You are joining us now, Davido, and I have to tell you, I listen to your music, I bought up to your music, it is so good, it has got Afrobeats. Why do you think that Afrobeats have really come into their own here in America? It has been mixed with everything, hip-hop, you name it. It's there. I hear it everywhere now.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO, SINGER
utterances.sentences: I mean, apart from the fact they're like everywhere like Africans are everywhere, like, you know, in the whole world, you know what I'm saying?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: But, you know, I feel like I was one of -- I moved out here. You know, coming out here when I was 15 years old, straight from Lagos, beating school. Even when I was in school, I used to play African music like 15 years ago, my friends, what's that? Oh, it's African music. They were like, oh, sounds (INAUDIBLE). You know what I'm saying? So, I always knew if we got the opportunity to be heard, I mean, like the western world would love it. You know what I was saying? So --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You were born in the states, you grew up in Nigeria.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was born in the states, went back home, and then came back out here for college. You know, that's when, you know, mixing of the cultures. So, I have lived in both worlds. I understand how to behave when I'm back home.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: How is that different? Tell us what is the difference.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: I know how to move when I'm here.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: How do you feel different? Like you go back and forth, right? You are the bridge.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: You are the bridge between the two worlds.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: I mean, it is amazing because I understand both cultures. You know, that's what I told you. I was like -- I know how to act when I'm back home. But the fusion of both cultures, that has helped me so much in my life. You know what I'm saying? In everything, in my music, in the way I relate with people, the way we do business, you know what I'm saying?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Is it -- first of all, it seems like the Nigerians have just taken over. it's like it's something --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: They're taking over Hollywood and everything else.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: It is more like sashimi?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: Fashion, you know, food --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Music, culture.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Music, culture.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: Film.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: So, what is it? Is it Nigeria Wakanda? Is that what it is? Tell me. Help me understand why you're taking over everything.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: Also, I feel like the Africans here became more confident to wrap us, to play the music outside. You know what I'm saying? Now, African DJs are proud to go out and get hosting and play in a club and have a whole Afrobeats set.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Unapologetic.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: You know what I'm saying? That was not happening. You know what I'm saying?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's all over social media, Instagram, TikTok. It's infused and so much. Here's the thing that we should ever forget. Those beats? They have been around. They have been around. They are part of what forms the music all over the world. This did not just come from nowhere, the Cubans, the Americans, you name --

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: Natural. Okay, let me give you a scenario. One day, just try it. So, let's say you are having a party and you play another genre. I don't want to name a genre. But yeah, you play a genre.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: Play it for, let's say, 30 minutes. After 30 minutes, just look around, and people are dancing, switching to Afrobeats. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I've seen that. There is a transformation.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: Something happens. It's amazing to see. So, it is unexplainable.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: You know what I am saying? You know, I'm just happy that finally, you know, so happy to walk in and say, like, you know, man, you guys don't know what you have done for us. We are proud to come out now and say, I am African. You know what I am saying? I'm saying, like, thank you and it is just amazing to see.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Part of what we said we wanted to do was have a global celebration for freedom. And you kind of brought the global to our celebration for freedom. I mean, Juneteenth isn't something that is just for the United States. It's about freedom. And freedom is an important movement in Africa as well.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: Exactly, definitely. It may be from both places.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Both places.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: It only makes sense for me to be out here celebrating this. A lot of people back home don't know about what Juneteenth.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: We sell out, you know, arenas out here. But that's like my fans. You know what I am saying?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You know when you go to concert --

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: When it is a Davido show, it was going to be lit. People are there for you. So, when I saw the lineup, I was like -- I like challenging myself. You know what I'm saying? I like doing something different sometimes. But when I was at the stage and picture came up --(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: They know me here?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: You know what I'm saying?  Shout out to my band. I'm playing with them for over 10 years now, (INAUDIBLE), a big Afrobeats band. Everything is just coming together. I'm wearing an African designer.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's great.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Freedom here, freedom back home, freedom all around the world.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: Everywhere.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: All right. And a little bit of bling.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Let's recognize. Thank you so much, Davido.

utterances.speaker: DAVIDO
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Okay, saxophone great, genius, I'm sorry, Mike Phillips jazzing up Juneteenth, having a set with "The Lady in My Life, doing his thing. Mike Phillips, so glad that you are here with us. How the heck do you hold those notes for so long with all that energy while dancing and going like this to the crowd?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: And to the crowd.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: How do you do it?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: -- dancer?

utterances.speaker: MIKE PHILLIPS, MUSICIAN
utterances.sentences: Listen, I'm everything. Back in high school, I used to play in a band and then play football, too.(LAUGHTER) Halftime, I would march with the band, and then go back and score a touchdown.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Wow. PHILLIPS

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: I think that people had no idea what was coming. You walk out on stage, you're carrying a saxophone, people are going to lay back for some Kenny G.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: You know, it's so crazy that you say that because I think, you know, Miles Davis was instrumental because he always had his pulse on the culture.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: The culture is a living organism that when it moves, we have to move with it. The culture dictates the rules. So, I think sometimes, we cannot cut off the culture and then move jazz to the suburbs and let it just live without the culture, dictating where to go.So (INAUDIBLE), what they do is the culture makes the rules and we just follow it. Do rights of passage because we are standing on the shoulders of Dizzy Gillespie, the great woman of jazz. Sarah Vaughan, Ella Fitzgerald. You know, I'm Charlie Parker. So, that show is about that.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: All present tonight. They were all president tonight.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: They were present tonight, they were present in you, and so many of the other performers. Stephanie Elam is down there. She was there in front, in person, watching this happened. I do want to quickly mention because we all have something in common, I think, with most of the world. Huge Prince fans. We were devastated when he left this earth. And you got a front row seat to see what Prince was all about because you played with him.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: Yes. He asked me to be in the new power generation. He looked me in the eye and I stared at him, and fell in love for about three seconds.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: We all did.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: I was like, I don't want to look, and then I looked and I said, oh my God!(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: And that's how I hooked up with my brother. He brought people together in the name of what it is to have great performances. But also, Prince taught me about the Nicholas brothers. He went back in history. So, you are not going to get on the stage with him unless you understood the history of the significance of what it is to have -- to be a real musician.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Steph is out there. Stephanie, if you have any questions, because I know you saw him and lost your mind.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: I did. And because I already -- I saw him before he left here. I'll be honest. I was like Mike Phillips! And now, I want to call him -- I just want to call you Mike Philly, if that is okay. Mike Philly. Mike Philly --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: That's good.

utterances.speaker: ELAM
utterances.sentences: And on top of it, I was watching the crowd and I was, like, okay, saxophone man, okay, all right, sure. And then at the end of it, everyone was on their feet. People were -- their minds were blown with him playing those notes. And then not just playing the notes but dancing and jumping while he was playing the notes. It was fantastic.But here's the thing, I have been listening to your music, Mike Philly, and I am trying to figure out how a man could be like, I'm going to play, lift every voice and sing the black national anthem, and then also do a rendition of "Three's Company," like "Legit," the TV show that we used to watch when we were kids, he has got a rendition of that on his album. The man has got range. You have no idea. (LAUGHTER) No one inspires you, Mike.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And it has not been one.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIPS
utterances.sentences: And if it hasn't been won, then the song is a beautiful mantra to keep marching and hoping and wishing for the best while making everyone accountable for where America is right now. But it can get better if we all work together.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Mike, it has been a privilege to share this concert, this holiday with all of you, and you, gentlemen, and you, Stephanie, and everyone at CNN. Happy Juneteenth. Mike Phillips, as a gift to us and the rest of the world that is watching, can you play a sound?
